channel.title: Video Game Graphics (PC vs Consoles)
channel.description:
A lot of people say they prefer console graphics over PC graphics. but if you look at it from this way may think differently.
Graphics on the PC are different for EVERYBODY. Some people like to use graphical mods... some just have bad systems. But trying to say graphics on the PC are bad is a bad sentence it self because everyone has a different look. Some like colors and bloom while others like realism. Now on a lot of games that are available on consoles AND PC have the problem of graphics being too artificial. Such as "FAKE HD" (Brown-ness, Bloom Overload, etc.). All of this done so that consoles can handle good looking graphics at a steady and good frame rate. But PC Gamers are effected by this. A lot of PC gamers have very good systems about 3x of a console. so when they have games like GTAIV come out the PC gamers have to deal with the "Fake HD".
Now with PC only games you can see a huge graphical difference. Look at ARMAII. If that game came out on the consoles it wouldn't look as good as it does on the PC, for a FACT. There are plenty of Graphx mods that will change the graphics of games that have "FAKE HD" for PC but are really time consuming for most to tweak and perfect.
Now i have played plenty of PC and Console games in my years and i have noticed all of the above to be very common.
What do you, as the community, think?

item.title: Video Game Graphics (PC vs Consoles)
item.dc:creator: Scrue
item.description:
PC > Console for almost anything really. at least graphics and control.

tycho_magnetic_anomaly_1:

Name a game with better graphics?

Minecraft.

item.title: Video Game Graphics (PC vs Consoles)
item.dc:creator: vivanto
item.description:
Katana:

Two [COLOR=‘Yellow’]eyes and a mouth are all that matter;

One of the most popular alien alien designs lacks that feature as well, but that’s more just nitpicking.

More importantly, why would a non-human-like fictional stuff be any more realistic than a human-like fictional stuff? It’s still just fictional stuff either way, where talking about realism is a moot point.

Read full topic

item.title: Video Game Graphics (PC vs Consoles)
item.dc:creator: Someonerandm
item.description:
Katana:

Bitching

Ultimately, if they wanted the aliens to be human, they’d give them faces. If they wanted them to be alien, and thus mysterious, they would make them
a) Hide behind their machines and
b) Not particularly human

Its really an obvious design choice that works. Alien aren’t humans, don’t make them humans.

Read full topic

item.title: Video Game Graphics (PC vs Consoles)
item.dc:creator: Surplus
item.description:
Katana:

There was something about the aliens that made me want to punch their character designer through the chest.

Do you know how easy it is to make a face?

The human mind interprets faces even where they’re not expected. Two eyes and a mouth are all that matter; it provides a human level of interaction, and lets you interpret that object/item/person/creature as a “character”. Now look at the Crysis aliens.

https://ui04.gamespot.com/707/screenshot0176.jpg (click)

Where’s the face? This thing just looks like one big amorphous machine. When it shoots me, it’s not “something trying to kill me”, it’s just “a machine that is launching particles at me in an effort to eliminate its target”. I realize the organic part is inside (heck, even that part doesn’t have a face), but even then you’re meant to get the feeling of a one-on-one struggle against something from another world. You don’t get that with this.

I realize it’s technically “realistic” that outer-world aliens would look nothing like humans, but as we’ve all said; realism does not make things good.

Yes, it does not have a face. However doesn’t that make it look all the more “Alien”. Well I understand what you mean about it not feeling like a foe, its simply a connotation you have developed with the idea of an enemy. For example an enemy in many games could be considered the ground, due to gravity it kills people. Some people I know die more from falls then actual opponents. It this case your enemy is an alien by definition it should not be familiar, even without looking at realism.

Read full topic

Are you implying the alien level was not incredibly appealing?

Do you know how easy it is to make a face?

The human mind interprets faces even where they’re not expected. Two eyes and a mouth are all that matter; it provides a human level of interaction, and lets you interpret that object/item/person/creature as a “character”. Now look at the Crysis aliens.

https://ui04.gamespot.com/707/screenshot0176.jpg (click)

Where’s the face? This thing just looks like one big amorphous machine. When it shoots me, it’s not “something trying to kill me”, it’s just “a machine that is launching particles at me in an effort to eliminate its target”. I realize the organic part is inside (heck, even that part doesn’t have a face), but even then you’re meant to get the feeling of a one-on-one struggle against something from another world. You don’t get that with this.

I realize it’s technically “realistic” that outer-world aliens would look nothing like humans, but as we’ve all said; realism does not make things good.

item.title: Video Game Graphics (PC vs Consoles)
item.dc:creator: Victus
item.description:
Maxey:

I still want to see Crysis 2 running maxed on a powerful computer.

Funny fact: Crysis 2 on E3 was actually running off a PC but with the graphical settings of the Xbox.

Via Fraps or external recording?

Also, Crysis has stunning visuals, though if you look at anything up close [trees, rocks, buildings] you can see the small pixels. Though in all honesty, if you’re staring at them long enough, you would probably end up dead.

One thing I noticed on the other spectrum, via Half-Life 2 is that the graphics are most definitely of good flavor and that makes the Hafl-Life 2 line up very enjoyable. It’s replay value it pretty good too, unlike Crysis I must say. I like playing up to the point you start killing aliens over and over, after that it’s just shootemup stuff.

Read full topic

item.title: Video Game Graphics (PC vs Consoles)
item.dc:creator: Surplus
item.description:
Katana:

I always thought Crysis had amazingly huge textures, but the environments were never that appealing or well-designed visually to me. I think that was why someone was saying Uncharted had the best graphics.

The problem with that is, when considering level design it comes to personally opinion. Textures and models have numbers people can slap on them to make it more black and white. Of course playing many games I would much rather have the attention of detail of Half-Life 2 than a higher poly/res hallway followed by a high poly/res field. But it’s difficult to argue which games level design is better.

Read full topic
